summary:
Automated fact-checking is gaining importance due to the increasing volume of online false information and the limitations of manual fact-checking [1]. This field leverages Natural Language Processing (NLP), information retrieval (IR), and big data mining to efficiently process large-scale textual information [1]. A key component of automated fact-checking is evidence retrieval, which involves finding relevant documents and snippets to challenge a claim [2]. Methods include snippet generation models, background knowledge retrieval, and reverse image search for multimedia content [2]. The goal is to save fact-checkers time and present evidence they might miss [2].

Automated verification approaches include checking against trusted sources, using machine learning to predict claim likelihood, and analyzing metadata [2]. A general-purpose framework for fully-automatic fact-checking uses a deep neural network with LSTM text encoding to combine semantic kernels with task-specific embeddings [3]. These embeddings encode a claim together with potentially relevant text fragments from the Web, while also considering source reliability [3]. The system converts claims into queries, retrieves relevant documents, and compares snippets and sentences from these documents to the claim [3].

Several fact-checking datasets, pipelines, and models have been developed, supported by shared tasks like RumourEval, CLEF CheckThat!, ClaimBuster, FEVER, SCIVER, Fake News Challenge, and HeroX fact checking challenge [1]. These datasets and shared tasks are crucial for advancing research in the field.

**References:**

[1] Abumansour, A. S., et al. (2020). Automated fact-checking: A survey. *Language and Linguistics Compass*, *14*(10), e12438. https://doi.org/10.1111/lnc3.12438

[2] Alam, F., et al. (2021). Automated Fact-Checking for Assisting Human Fact-Checkers. *Proceedings of the Thirtieth International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence*, 4308-16. https://doi.org/10.24963/ijcai.2021/619

[3] Barron-Cedeno, A., et al. (2018). Fully Automated Fact Checking Using External Sources. *Advances in Artificial Intelligence*, 491-500. https://doi.org/10.26615/978-954-452-049-6_046
